speaker: Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series
text: Derek Jacobi  * * *  ## Transcript {Mike Lee}  _    ACT ONE  Scene One - Convention Center Frasier and Roz walk into a Science-Fiction Expo._

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, I knew when you bought me lunch there was going to be a catch!  How long is this gonna take?
prevSpeaker: Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it shouldn't take too long, Roz.  I can't believe I'm actually scouring a science-fiction convention for "X-Men" comics.  I feel like I'm contributing to the decline of my son's intellect.

speaker: Roz
text: Then why are you doing it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, because I said no to the eyebrow ring.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh excuse me, good sir, um, could you direct me please to Cubby's World of Comics?

speaker: Klingon
text: Yeah, it's right over there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you, thank you very much.  You are a fierce but helpful people. _He turns to head for the comics booth but stops when he sees a British man in his sixties signing autographs at a table._  [_N.B. This is Sir Derek Jacobi's first appearance in an American television production._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Good lord, that's Jackson Hedley.

speaker: Roz
text: Who?

speaker: Frasier
text: Jackson Hedley, the famous Shakespearean actor.  He came to my school when I was a teen.  He did a one-man show of soliloquies, and began my love affair with the Bard!  Excuse me Roz, I think I'll just go pay my respects to Mr. Hedley.  _Frasier makes his way over to Jackson's table, and stands in line behind a portly long-haired man (Dwayne)._

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, um, what's Jackson Hedley doing here?

speaker: Dwayne
text: Signing autographs, and being awesome!  They've got the whole cast of "Space Patrol" coming this weekend!

speaker: Frasier
text: You mean Jackson Hedley was on a television show?

speaker: Dwayne
text: What, are you kidding?  He's Tobor, the ship's android! Where've you been, man?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know.  Reading, attending the theater, [_under his breath_] getting haircuts.  [_N.B. Derek Jacobi is not the only great Shakespearean actor playing against type in this episode; Ray Porter, who plays Dwayne, is a long- time member of the Oregon Shakespeare Festival Company in Ashland, Oregon.  I saw him on the stage as Moliere, and as Tullus Aufidius in "Coriolanus."  He's got an awesome presence!  So, we have two facets of the same inside joke ;-) - Mike Lee_] _At the other side of the room, Noel Shempsky and a friend, both wearing old-style "Star Trek" uniforms, see Roz._

speaker: Noel
text: Hi, Roz!

speaker: Roz
text: [_horrified_] Hi, Noel.

speaker: Noel
text: So you're a closet Trekker!  I always had a feeling we were more than mere coworkers.  This explains the heat between us.

speaker: Roz
text: I feel heat all right - because I'm in hell!

speaker: Jackson
text: There you are, Dwayne.

speaker: Dwayne
text: Thanks, Tobor.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Mr. Hedley.  Uh, may I say, it's an honor to see you again.

speaker: Jackson
text: Thank you.  So what would you like to be autographed today?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, I already have your autograph.  I got it after seeing your performance of "Hamlet."

speaker: Jackson
text: Oh, my... that was a long time ago.

speaker: Frasier
text: But not forgotten.  May I say, on behalf of my brother and myself, thank you for opening our young eyes to the wonders of Shakespeare.

speaker: Jackson
text: You are more than welcome.

speaker: Frasier
text: Tell me, do you get to do much theater anymore?

speaker: Jackson
text: Oh no, I'm afraid those days are over.  The show became so popular.  I can't get cast as anything but an android, a cyborg, or, when I get the chance to really spread my wings, a mutant.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah well, what a shame.  For you, and the theater.

speaker: Jackson
text: Oh, you are very kind.  Well, my fans await.  It was lovely meeting you, Mr....?

speaker: Frasier
text: Frasier Crane.  Thank you, Mr. Hedley.

speaker: Frasier
text: It just breaks my heart to see that man reduced to this. It's so demeaning.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, so he's not doing Shakespeare.  But look, he's got tons of fans that worship him!  What's so demeaning about that?

speaker: Fan
text: Hey, Tobor, would you do my kid's birthday party?

speaker: Jackson
text: [_sighs and gives him a card_] Here's my card.  Uh, travel time is extra, and I eat by myself.  _Frasier and Roz exchange a shudder.  FADE OUT  Scene Two - Apartment Frasier is sitting on the couch.  Niles comes in carrying a suitcase, followed by Martin and Eddie._

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, look who I found at the airport!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh-ho, welcome home, Dad!  So, how was Florida?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it was a whirlwind!  Duke and I hit the dog track, and then we met the "Michael Jordan of High-Life Players" at the Red Lobster, but the place I went back to most of all was Cap'n Pete's Gator Farm.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, did you go see the Hemingway home?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you know Fras, you can't squeeze everything in. But I tell you, these gators are amazing!  You're out in the Glades in this fanboat, and it's just you and Cap'n Pete and that cooler full of raw chickens!

speaker: Niles
text: And to think I wasted my last vacation in Vienna.

speaker: Martin
text: And then he dangles a chicken at the end of the stick, and before you know it a fifteen-foot monster comes rushing out of the water, and he's yelling, "Hurry up and take the picture, this sumbitch is heavy!" [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: That's delightful, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Where's Daphne?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, my honeybunny has the flu.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's too bad. [_aside to Frasier_] Probably got it standing in front of an open refrigerator.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughs_] Nice to have you back, Dad.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: You will never guess what I found.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hmm?

speaker: Niles
text: This is the autograph Jackson Hedley gave me in junior high school.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, Niles. [_reading_] "Dear Coach Palet, please excuse Niles from gym, for obvious reasons."

speaker: Niles
text: The other side.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes.  "To Niles, my kingdom for more fans like you. Jackson Hedley."  That's lovely.

speaker: Niles
text: 'Course, I'm still envious that you got to see him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you wouldn't be if you'd been at that convention, Niles. To see the man who defined Hamlet reduced to hawking t-shirts and sci-fi gee-gaws.

speaker: Niles
text: It's a terrible waste of talent.

speaker: Frasier
text: Tragic.  No artist should have to endure that.

speaker: Niles
text: If only people could see him the way we did.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, how difficult would it be to mount Jackson's one-man show?  It's relatively simple.

speaker: Niles
text: That's true: there's minimal scenery, no supporting ca-... wait a minute, are you suggesting-

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, why not?  There's certainly no shortage of theaters in this town.

speaker: Niles
text: We could do it on a Monday night when they're all dark anyway.

speaker: Frasier
text: We could revive the man's career, just think what a gift it would be to return this man to the stage, where he belongs!

speaker: Niles
text: It would be like repaying him for giving us the gift of Shakespeare!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and if the evening goes very well, then who knows? We could be in for a long run, we might even take it on the road!

speaker: Niles
text: Why not a television special, we'd reach a much larger audience!

speaker: Frasier
text: It could become a cottage industry!  T-shirts, posters, personal appearances!

speaker: Niles
text: Thank God we've come along to save this man!  _They clink glasses.  FADE TO:_  **TROTTING THE BARDS**  _Scene Three - Theater Frasier and Niles walk onto the empty stage._

speaker: Frasier
text: Gosh Niles, I can't wait to show Jackson his new venue. Gosh, what an honor it is to be reuniting such a great talent with the stage.  Is he here yet?

speaker: Niles
text: No, he's cutting the opening ribbon at Galaxy Mattresses.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, once this show opens he'll be able to throw away his oversize novelty shears.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, yes.  Oh, I just came from the box office.  Ticket sales are going at quite a brisk pace.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm not surprised.  I've got half the station coming.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I've got a whole group coming from the wine club.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you know, Niles, we've really done a good job of getting the word out.  That's why we get to be producers.

speaker: Jackson
text: Hello, lads!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Mr. Hedley.  Please, join us on the stage.

speaker: Frasier
text: Or shall we say, on your stage.

speaker: Jackson
text: [_does so, breathless_] Oh, it's been such a - such a long time since I've trod the boards.  Do you really think people are going to pay money to see me?  After all these years?

speaker: Niles
text: The way things are going, we expect a sell-out!

speaker: Frasier
text: One week from today, you'll be looking out on a packed house!

speaker: Jackson
text: Really?  Do you know, the one thing that I-I don't miss about performing live, it's-it's the jitters. [_breathing heavy_] It's the [_dry heaves_] dry heaves.  Maybe this wasn't the best idea!

speaker: Niles
text: No, sir!

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, please.  The theater is your true destiny.  It courses through your veins, it fills your lungs.  This... is _your_ stage.  Welcome home.

speaker: Jackson
text: And you said you'd never produced before. _Jackson takes center stage.  Frasier stands to stage left and extends a hand to the empty seats._

speaker: Frasier
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I bring you to a hall in Elsinore Castle.

speaker: Niles
text: [_extending his own hand_] Denmark!  _Frasier slaps his hand down.  Jackson begins with a loud groan, delivering a monologue from "Hamlet" so over-the-top as to make Vivien Leigh seem shy._

speaker: Jackson
text: Ohhhhhh, I die, Horatio! [_gasp_] The potent poison quite o'er-crows my spirit! [_gasp_] I cannot live to hear the news from England, But I do prophesy the election lights On Fortinbras; [_gasp, lies down_] he has my dying voice. the rest is... [_exaggerated whisper_] silence! [_gasp_] - [_Hamlet, Act V, Scene 2_] _"Hamlet" dies.  Frasier and Niles have just watched their dream castle crumble to the ground with numb horror._

speaker: Jackson
text: [_getting up_] You know, you boys were right!  It's as if I never left!  _Niles is openly gaping; Frasier wears that little nervous smile he reserves for squirming.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Four - Apartment Frasier is seated at the coffee table.  Martin comes out with some snapshots._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey Fras, I just got my alligator pictures back.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh!

speaker: Martin
text: Take a look.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mm-hmm. [_does_] Yes.

speaker: Martin
text: That's Cap'n Pete.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.

speaker: Martin
text: That's the gator boat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh-huh.

speaker: Martin
text: That's a chicken.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, and that's him: the one I call Snappy.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_last photo_] What's that?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's Duke's bypass scar.  I had to use up the roll.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we'll have to look at these later, Dad.  That'll be Niles, he's here to discuss our show.

speaker: Martin
text: You want a show?  Well, take a tip from me, Mr. Producer: one alligator, one chicken, one satisfied audience.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh hello, Niles, come on in.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I got your message, it sounded urgent.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, it's about Jackson.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh please, don't tell me he's getting any worse.  Yesterday I saw the stagehands passing out earplugs.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's not his fault!  He's only rusty!  After years on that ridiculous space opera, he's picked up some bad habits! Well, I was fortunate enough to find a videotape of his one-man show.  Once he sees this, it will remind him of what good acting is; you know, shake loose the artist from the android!

speaker: Niles
text: That, sir, is why you are the first "Crane" in "Crane & Crane Productions!"

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, thank you.  All right, listen, Jackson's on his way over here.  Let's take a quick peek at this.

speaker: Niles
text: Good idea.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, his Lear.  Oh gosh, that brings back memories. Here, let me turn up the volume. [_does_]

speaker: Jackson
text: [_on TV_] Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks!  Rage, blow! You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout till you have drrrrrrrrrrrrench'd our steeples, drrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrown'd the cocks! -[_King Lear, Act III, Scene 2_]  Frasier mutes it again._

speaker: Niles
text: He's awful.

speaker: Frasier
text: The man has no instincts.  Just stinks.

speaker: Niles
text: I guess we were just too young to know it.  Frasier, this is going to be humiliating - not just for us, but for Jackson. What are we gonna do?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_thinks, then gets up_] What all good producers do: we'll shut down and blame the director!

speaker: Frasier
text: That'll be Jackson now.  All we have to do is get Jackson to bow out gracefully, and we'll refund all the tickets.

speaker: Jackson
text: Hello, lads!

speaker: Frasier
text: Please come in, Mr. Hedley.

speaker: Jackson
text: Ah, you must be the Crane pater!  It is a pleasure to encounter the headwaters whence bridge these twin rivers upon which I have launched my humble craft.

speaker: Martin
text: Likewise. [_goes to his room_] I'm telling you: one gator, one chicken.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, Mr. Hedley, won't you sit down?

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah.

speaker: Jackson
text: [_does_] Oh, I see my producers have long faces.  I think I know why.

speaker: Frasier
text: You do?

speaker: Jackson
text: Well, it's obvious, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: It is to us.

speaker: Jackson
text: Well, your worries are at an end: I fired the director! The man's a clod!  I mean, not even the stagehands follow his directions!  He shouts at them and they pretend not to hear.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mr. Hedley, it's not the director.  We have a problem.

speaker: Jackson
text: What sort of problem?

speaker: Frasier
text: Let me be frank, because an artist of your caliber deserves honesty... an acting performance is a journey of discovery. This brief rehearsal time that we've given you is-is far too short to reach Parnassus, home of the Muses.

speaker: Niles
text: Forgive us for being so blunt.

speaker: Jackson
text: Ah, I see!  We're getting to the real problem: I've got untested producers, and they've got the jitters.  Ah, but not to worry, it's perfectly natural!  Do you know I've never worked with producers who haven't wanted to pull the plug before the opening night?  But I won't let you quit! This show is going on!  In the words of our great author, "stiffen the sinews!  Summon up the blood!  Disguise fair nature with hard-favored [_nearly falsetto_] rage!  They lend the eye a terrible aspect!" _He caps this off with an exaggerated lowering of his brow that succeeds only in squinting his eyes.  He leaves._

speaker: Niles
text: I think he's getting better, don't you? **CURTAINS**  _Scene Five - Theater Frasier and Niles, wearing tuxedoes, are peering from the stage wing out into the audience, which is packed._

speaker: StageManager
text: **[_o.s._] Fifteen minutes to curtain!

speaker: Frasier
text: Look out there.  Everybody we know is out there.  Look at all those smiling faces, soon to be frozen into a rictus of revenge!

speaker: Niles
text: The place is packed!

speaker: Frasier
text: It's standing room only! [_gets an idea_] You know, Niles... I think we may have exceeded maximum occupancy.

speaker: Niles
text: That could be... a fire hazard.

speaker: Frasier
text: It would be a shame if someone should... call the fire marshal and he should shut us down.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, it would.  A damn shame if the old phone in the marshal's office should start to ching-ching-ching...

speaker: Frasier
text: Just call!

speaker: Manager
text: Ten minutes to curtain!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm-I'm sorry, I-I believe that your watch happens to be a tad fast.

speaker: Manager
text: It's electromagnetically set to Greenwich Mean Time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Get me a Sprite!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, the marshal will be here as quickly as he can. There's a five-alarmer in the paper district.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just our luck!

speaker: Niles
text: What are we going to do now?

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, guys!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz!

speaker: Roz
text: This is Jackson Hedley's father, I found him wandering around out front looking for Jackson.

speaker: Frasier
text: Lovely to see you.

speaker: Cecil
text: Thank God I'm not late!  You know, I'm Jackson's lucky charm. Do you know, he's so superstitious - one day I didn't turn up for opening night, and he refused to go on.

speaker: Niles
text: Is that so?

speaker: Frasier
text: Then we must get you to him immediately!  You see, you're at the wrong theater!

speaker: Cecil
text: Oh!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, Jackson's performing clear across town!

speaker: Cecil
text: But the sign outside says "An Evening With Jackson Hedley!"

speaker: Frasier
text: I know, you see, there's been a terrible snafu-

speaker: Niles
text: Snafu!

speaker: Frasier
text: -with the marquee letters.  You see, they got ours, we got theirs.

speaker: Cecil
text: Oh, what's playing here?

speaker: Niles
text: "Cats."

speaker: Cecil
text: Ah, I love "Cats."

speaker: Frasier
text: Who doesn't, but surely you love your son more!

speaker: Frasier
text: This young lady knows this town inside and out!  Roz, please escort Mr. Hedley to the Portland Playhouse A.S.A.P.!

speaker: Roz
text: But-

speaker: Frasier
text: There's no time for buts, please do it now!

speaker: Roz
text: Right, let's go, Mr. Hedley.

speaker: Cecil
text: Oh please, call me Cecil.

speaker: Roz
text: All right, Cecil.

speaker: Cecil
text: Do you know, I have a predilection for brunettes.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, should we go break the bad news to our star?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes! _They go into Jackson's dressing room.  Jackson is dressed as Hamlet and singing an aria._

speaker: Frasier
text: Mr. Hedley, I'm afraid we have some bad news.

speaker: Niles
text: It's about your father, it seems his plane is going to be late.

speaker: Jackson
text: What, you mean my father won't make it for the show?!

speaker: Frasier
text: We know this must be devastating to you-

speaker: Jackson
text: On the contrary!  For once my performance won't be inhibited by that judgmental nitpicker!  Tonight I can really cut loose! Those seats in the very back row will be rattling!

speaker: Frasier
text: That is good news.

speaker: Manager
text: Five minutes to curtain. [_leaves_]

speaker: Jackson
text: And now if you'll excuse me, it's time to center. _He closes his eyes and breathes deeply.  Frasier and Niles go back out into the hall._

speaker: Niles
text: Any more ideas?

speaker: Manager
text: These are the producers.  The, uh, fire marshal's here.

speaker: Marshal
text: Do you guys have any idea how many people you got out there? You're way over capacity.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're not gonna shut us down, are you?

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I knew we shouldn't have added all those dry wooden seats.

speaker: Marshal
text: Well, maybe next time you'll know better.

speaker: Jackson
text: Has anyone seen my other skull?

speaker: Frasier
text: Mr. Hedley, I'm afraid we have some bad news-

speaker: Marshal
text: Hey, you're Tobor!

speaker: Jackson
text: Oh, correct.

speaker: Marshal
text: I used to watch your show all the time!  I even have that old Playboy when Space Princess Alexa did that spread.

speaker: Jackson
text: Oh, the one on the lava rocks?  Yes, I've got that one too.

speaker: Marshal
text: I didn't know he was the one performing tonight.  I'll let you guys stay open, on one condition: I get to watch the show.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_last try_] We're out of seats!

speaker: Marshal
text: It's OK, I'll sit in the aisle.

speaker: Manager
text: Three minutes to curtain!

speaker: Jackson
text: [_finds his skull_] Ah, here's the right one!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, we may as well just take our lumps.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no!  We're not going to take any lumps! Desperate times call for desperate measures!

speaker: Niles
text: What are you doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Shield yourself, Niles, "for the rain, it raineth everyday!" _Niles finds an Oriental rain hat and puts it on.  Frasier climbs up, ignites a cigarette lighter and holds it under the alarm.  The sprinkler over him goes off, trickling a pathetically fine mist over him.  None of the other sprinklers go off._

speaker: Frasier
text: This place really is a deathtrap!

speaker: Niles
text: This is hopeless.

speaker: Cecil
text: I managed to shake that woman, I want to see "Cats!"

speaker: Cecil
text: Son!

speaker: Jackson
text: [_feigning_] Father!  My good luck charm!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God!  Oh Mr. Hedley, are you all right?

speaker: Jackson
text: I think I've broken something!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh my God, [_to the stage manager_] call an ambulance! Make sure Mr. Hedley is comfortable!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God, Niles, I feel horrible.  It's as if we wished it, and it happened.

speaker: Niles
text: Half of me feels guilty, the other half feels relieved. Actually, it's about 30-70.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I guess I'd better go out and make an announcement. _They grin at each other and flash thumbs-up.  Frasier goes out onto the main stage._

speaker: Frasier
text: If I may have your attention, ladies and gentlemen.  Tonight my brother Niles Crane and I had hoped to bring a great talent back to the stage.  A truly, truly gifted actor, a man we greatly admire...  _Unseen by Frasier, Jackson crawls onstage, dragging himself with his hands.  The audience starts to applaud._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_claps his hands_] Yes, yes, he does deserve your applause, but in a tragedy befitting of the Bard himself, it seems that...  _He trails off as Jackson pulls himself across the stage and into the chair set up there for his soliloquy._

speaker: Frasier
text: ...it seems he's ready to begin.  Ladies and gentlemen, I bring you now to a hall... in Elsinore Castle.

speaker: Jackson
text: Ohhhhhhhhh, I die, Horatio! [_gasp_]
